name: Saxhóll Crater
description: Saxhóll is a striking volcanic scoria cone rising 45 meters high and 100 meters above the surrounding lava fields near the westernmost tip of the Snæfellsnes Peninsula within Snæfellsjökull National Park. This cinder cone formed between 3,000 and 4,000 years ago during mildly explosive eruptions from a single vent that shot molten rock fragments high into the air, which then fell back to earth and solidified into the loose volcanic material—scoria and ash—that characterizes the cone today. The crater consists almost entirely of basaltic tephra ejected from lava fountains, with a central depression filled with black sand and scattered volcanic rocks. What makes Saxhóll particularly accessible and popular is the award-winning metal staircase consisting of 396 steps that spirals from the parking area at the base to an observation platform at the crater's rim. This solid, safe structure wraps around the crater in a gradual ascent, making it manageable for visitors of most ages and fitness levels, typically taking just 5 to 10 minutes to climb. The staircase itself has become an architectural landmark, winning the prestigious Rosa Barba International Landscape Prize in 2018—the fourth award the project received since 2017—for its elegant integration of modern infrastructure with Iceland's dramatic natural landscape. The shallow gradient of the metal stairs ensures accessibility while minimizing environmental impact on the fragile volcanic terrain.
